chapter.title: Composition of Functions and Inverses of Functions

li.p: Define composite functions and combinations of functions and apply and interpret these in appropriate situations.
Evaluate, apply, and interpret function notation, including the notation for inverse functions and composition of functions.
Demonstrate the inverse relationship between an exponential function and a logarithmic function (with the same base).

section.title: Gist of Composition and Inverses of Functions

subsection.title: Composition
subsection.p: The compositionfunctioncompositionfunction composition of functions is all about using the output of one function as the input for another.
The notation we will use for composing two functions is f(g(x)) which we read as "f of g of x".
Working from the inside-out, this means that the function g is used first to get an output, and then that output is used as the input for the function f.

statement.p: Suppose f(x) = 3x + 4 and g(x) = x^2 + x. Compute each of the following compositions. Remember to work inside the parentheses first.

li.p: f(g(5)). We can first work inside the parentheses to find the value of g(5), and then use that value as the input for f. f(g(5)) \amp= f\mathopen{}\left(5^2 + 5\right)\mathclose{} \amp= f(30) \amp= 3\cdot30 + 4 \amp= 94
g(f(5)). We can first work inside the parentheses to find the value of f(5), and then use that value as the input for g. g(f(5)) \amp= g(3\cdot5 + 4) \amp= g(19) \amp= 19^2 + 19 \amp= 380

So we found:

subsection.p: functioncompositecomposite functionIf we use function composition with a numerical input, we will get a numerical output. However, if we just use x as the input and compose functions, the result will be an expression involving x, which is a brand new function representing the composition. This new function is called a composite function.

note.p: Often, the composite function f(g(x)) is written as (f \circ g)(x) to indicate that (f \circ g) is a new function.
Similarly, the composite functions g(f(x)) and f(f(x)) would be written as (g \circ f)(x) and (f \circ f)(x).

statement.p: Let f(x) = 3x + 4 and g(x) = x^2 + x. Find the composite functions (f \circ g) and (g \circ f) by using x as the input. Remember to simplify the expression inside the parentheses first.

li.p: f(g(x)). We can first substitute the expression for g(x) inside the parentheses, and then use that expression as the input for f. f(g(x)) \amp= f\mathopen{}\left(x^2 + x\right)\mathclose{} \amp= 3\left(x^2 + x\right) + 4 \amp= 3x^2 + 3x + 4

g(f(x)). We can first substitute the expression for f(x) inside the parentheses, and then use that expression as the input for g. g(f(x)) \amp= g(3x + 4) \amp= (3x + 4)^2 + (3x + 4) \amp= 9x^2 + 24x + 16 + 3x + 4 \amp= 9x^2 + 27x + 20

statement.p:
So we found:

subsection.p: Notice something important about the composite formula you found for g(f(x)) in Exercise: Using x as the input, you found that g(f(x)) = 9x^2 + 27x + 20. Evaluating this new formula at the input x = 5 gives: 9(5)^2 + 27(5) + 20 \amp= 9\cdot25 + 27\cdot5 + 20 \amp= 225 + 135 + 20 \amp= 380
This is exactly the same result you got when you evaluated g(f(5)) in Exercise.

The formula g(f(x)) = 9x^2 + 27x + 20 is really a new, single function that represents the composition f(g(x)). Once you've found this formula, you could quickly evaluate many numerical compositions, such as g(f(7)) or g(f(-3.6)), without having to think about g and f separately.

Turning two or more functions into one function by composition is really a common idea think about any complex machine, such as an automobile. Many internal processes depend on each other, and you may think of the following simplifications:

li.p: Applying pressure to the accelerator pedal allows air into sthe fuel system.
The air in the system is monitored, and fuel is added to the system accordingly.
Spark plugs ignite the fuel mixture.
Etc.

subsection.p: Now, few people would look at a car and see it as a composition of its dozens of connected systems and processes. We just simplify this by assigning a single word to refer to this complex composite function: car.
If everything is working properly, from the driver's perspective, there is just one input depressing the accelerator that sets everything else in motion.

This is true for any composition of functions in mathematics. Even if we have something complicated like: f(g(h(x))) There is just one input value, x, that is needed in order to evaluate the composite function.
The next example uses function composition in the context of a patient taking blood pressure medicine.

example.p: Let C represent the concentration, measured in , of a blood pressure regulating drug in a patient's bloodstream as a function of time t, measured in hours. As time goes on, the concentration of the drug in the bloodstream decreases as the body metabolizes and/or excretes it.
At the same time, the drug is meant to help lower the patient's blood pressure P, measured in Hg. So, as the drug leaves the patient's bloodstream, the blood pressure increases.
Therefore, P depends on C, and C depends on t.
There is a function which represents how C depends on t. We will call this function f, and write: C = f(t)
There is another function which represents how P depends on C. We will call this function g, and write: P = g(C)

So, we would first use f(t) to find the concentration C of the drug in the bloodstream, and then use that concentration as the input for the function g(C) in order to find the patient's blood pressure P.
In function notation, this would look like: P \amp= g(C) \amp=g(f(t))
That last expression, g(f(t)), is a composite function, and it shows that the blood pressure is really a function of t.

subsection.p: Continue Example in the next exercise, evaluating the composition with a numerical input.

statement.p: The blood pressure drug lisinopril works best when it is consumed at an initial concentration of 5 mg/Kg, and its concentration decreases exponentially, with a half-life of 12 hours.
Therefore, the concentration can be modeled by the function C = f(t) = 5e^{-0.058t} where t represents the number of hours after it was consumed.

Suppose that a patient with hypertension is admitted with blood pressure at 160 mm Hg. Administering the drug at a concentration of 5 mg/Kg reduces their blood pressure to 110 mm Hg. As the drug's concentration decreases over time, their blood pressure increases linearly, returning to 160 mm Hg when the concentration drops to 1 mg/Kg.
Therefore, the expected blood pressure can be modeled by the function:P = g(C) = -12.5C + 172.5

C = f() = mg/Kg
What is the expected blood pressure after hours?
P = g(f()) = mm Hg
Evaluate f(20) by using the formula: f(20) = 5e^{0.058()}
Now take the value of f() and use it as the input for the function g.
The concentration after hours is , and its value is mg/Kg.
The blood pressure after hours is , and its value is mm Hg.

subsection.p: Finally, we conclude Example by finding the formula for a composite function.

statement.p: What is the correct formula for the composite function g(f(t))?

hint.p: Try writing the function g(C), but use the formula for f(t) in the place of C.

solution.p: The correct formula for g(f(t)) is: -12.5\left(5e^{-0.058t}\right)+172.5\text{.}

Note that the second option 5e^{-0.058(-12.5C+172.5)} is actually the composite function f(g(C)), which really makes no sense in context. The output for g(C) is the blood pressure, and that is not the correct input for the function f(t).

The last option \left(-12.5C+172\right)\left(5e^{-0.058t}\right) is actually the product f(t)\cdot g(C), which again does not make sense in context. This would result in multiplying the outputs of f(t) and g(C), so the output would be concentration multiplied by blood pressure.
It is almost always helpful to think about the units when evaluating functions in an applied context.

subsection.p: Even outside of a context, knowing how to write a formula for a composite function is an important skill.

paragraphs.title: Transformations are Compositions
paragraphs.p: In chapter, you studied transformations of a function. There, you took a function f(x) and shifted its graph left or right by adding a number to the input of the function. For instance, f(x â€“ 3) represented shifting the graph y = f(x) to the right by 3 units.
However, this may also be thought of as the composition of two functions: f(x) and g(x) = x - 3

As a composition, this transformation occurs by substituting the function g(x) = x - 3 into the function f(x):f(x - 3) = f(g(x))So, we have already been using function composition, though we have waited until now to give it that name.

subsection.title: Inverses
subsection.p: Two functions are called inversesfunctioninverseinverse function if they undo each other. If one function has a certain process, then the other function will have the reverse process.
Using function notation, this means the following:

assemblage.p: If f and g are inverses, then both of the following will be true:

subsection.p: This is because whatever the inside function did with the input x, the outside function undid that action.
If a function f has an inverse function f^{-1}, then we say that the function f is invertiblefunctioninvertibleinvertible function (also called one-to-oneone-to-onefunctionone-to-one).

example.p: The functions f(x) = 2^x + 1 and g(x) = \log_{2}(x - 1) are inverses.
In order to show this, we would use function composition to show that both of the conditions above are true. f(g(x)) \amp= f(\log_{2}(x - 1)) \amp= 2^{\log_{2}(x - 1)} + 1 \amp= (x - 1) + 1 \amp= x
This shows that f(g(x)) = x. Similarly, we have: g(f(x)) \amp= g(2^x+1) \amp= \log_{2}\left((2^x+1)-1\right) \amp= \log_{2}\left(2^x\right) \amp= x

paragraphs.title: Notation
paragraphs.p: If h(x) is a function, then its inverse is called h^{-1}. This notation does not mean that h is being raised to a negative exponent rather, it is just special notation for an inverse function.
We use this special notation either when we want to talk about the inverse of some function, or when we want to find the formula for the inverse.

paragraphs.title: Interpreting the notation
paragraphs.p: If f takes an input a and gives an output b, then its inverse f^{-1} would take b as the input and give the output a.
Since a function and its inverse represent reverse processes, the input and output are similarly reversed.

paragraphs.title: Domain and Range Connection
paragraphs.p: A function and its inverse trade inputs and outputs. Recall Exercise, where the function used degrees Fahrenheit as the input, and gave degrees Celsius as the output. The inverse for this function would use degrees Celsius as the input and give degrees Fahrenheit as the output.
You probably own a trimmed-down version of this function, as seen below:

subsection.p: This is clearly an invertible function, changing degrees Fahrenheit into degrees Celsius. We choose an input value (degrees Fahrenheit) on one side of the thermometer, and read the corresponding output (degrees Celsius) on the other side.
If we gave this function the name C = g(F), then the domain is 32 \leqslant F \leqslant 212 and the range is 0 \leqslant C \leqslant 100.
Of course, we could also read the thermometer in reverse, using degrees Celsius as the input and degrees Fahrenheit as the output. This would be the inverse function, written as: F = g^{-1}(C)
Notice that the domain and range have been switched for the inverse function. Now F = g^{-1}(C) has domain 0 \leqslant C \leqslant 100 and range: 32 \leqslant F \leqslant 212
This observation will be true for all invertible functions:

paragraphs.title: The Inverse Formula
paragraphs.p: If we have the formula for a function f(x), we may want to use the formula for the inverse f^{-1}(x).
But how can we find the formula?

statement.p: If you deposit \$500 into a savings account that earns 3\% interest per year, and you make no additional deposits or withdrawals, then your account balance can be found by the function B(t) = 500(1.03)^t where t represents the number of years after making the original deposit of \$500, and B(t) represents the balance in the account after t years.
For this function, the input is years and the output is dollars. You would use a number of years, say 12, and B(12) would calculate how many dollars are in the account.

The inverse function B^{-1} would switch these, using dollars for the input and years for the output. Here, you would use an amount of money, say \$925, and B^{-1}(925) would calculate how many years it would take to have that much in the account.
In order to find the value of B^{-1}(925), we could solve for t in the equation: 500\cdot1.03^t = 925
Solve this equation to find the value of B^{-1}(925).

solution.p: It would take about 20.81 years for the account to grow to \$925.

statement.p: If you had to repeatedly answer questions like those in Example, you would find yourself solving the same equation each time.
Instead, you could just find the formula for the inverse function B^{-1} and use it to directly calculate the number of years required.
To do this, use the fact that B and B^{-1} undo each other. In particular: B\mathopen{}\left(B^{-1}(x)\right)\mathclose{} = x
Now, use this inverse function to determine how long it would take for there to be \$1200 in the account.

solution.p: It would take about 29.62 years for the account to grow to \$1200.

paragraphs.title: What makes a function invertible
paragraphs.p: Remember the defining characteristic of a function:

blockquote.p: For each input, there is only one output.

paragraphs.p: Thinking about the graph, this means that there can be at most one point with any given x-coordinate. That is, no two points on the graph of a function can be directly above or below each other.
Now, if an inverse f^{-1} is really a function, then it must also obey this rule. No two points on the graph of y = f^{-1}(x) can sit directly above or below each other.
So if f^{-1} is a function, this has an implication for the original function f.

To see this, remember that the graphs of a function and its inverse are reflections of each other over the line y = x. If no two points on the graph of an inverse function can sit above or below each other, then reflecting these points over y = x means that no two points on the graph of f(x) can sit directly left or right of each other.

subsection.p:
Graphically, we have these two rules:
Vertical Line Test
A vertical line may only intersect the graph of a function at most once. If some vertical line could intersect the graph more than once, then the graph is not a function.
Horizontal Line Test
horizontal line testIf a function is invertible, then its graph may only intersect a horizontal line at most once. If a horizontal line could intersect the graph more than once, then the graph is not invertible.

example.p: As an example of using the Horizontal Line Test, the function f(x) = x^2 does not have an inverse function, since the horizontal line y = 4 intersects the graph of f(x) twice, at the points (2, 4) and (-2, 4). See Figure.
Conversely, the function g(x) = x^3 does have an inverse function, since no horizontal line can intersect the graph more than once. See Figure.

paragraphs.title: Restricting the Domain
paragraphs.p: You may object to the notion that f(x) = x^2 is non-invertible, because surely the function g(x) = \sqrt{x} performs the opposite action.
However, this is only true because we define \sqrt{x} so that it never gives negative outputs. [Check this on your calculator!]
For example, we have two inputs which give the same output for the function f(x)=x^2: f(5) = 5^2 = 25 f(-5) = (-5)^2 = 25
Since an inverse function would reverse the input and the output, it would need to somehow use 25 as the input, and then output both 5 and -5.
But because g(x) = \sqrt{x} is a function, it can only give the single output 5.

Therefore, when we use g(x)=\sqrt{x} as the inverse for f(x)=x^2, we have decided to use only part of the domain of f so that its inverse, g, is really a function. This is called restricting the domain.

Now shrink the interval until the inverse is a function. What interval would make the inverse a function?

solution.p: If we restrict the domain of f(x) = x^2 to x \geq 0, then it is invertible. The inverse function is f^{-1}(x) = \sqrt{x}.

subsection.title: Conclusion
subsection.p: We have seen that a composite function is built from using the output of one function as the input for another function.
If a function never has any repeated output values, then it is said to be invertible or one-to-one. It passes the horizontal line test.
For an invertible function f, its inverse function f^{-1} performs the opposite action as f. If you compose a function with its inverse f^{-1}(f(x)) or f(f^{-1}(x)), the result will be x.

The graphs of a function and its inverse will be reflections of each other over the line y = x. Any point (a,b) on the graph of y = f(x) will correspond to a point (b,a) on the graph of y = f^{-1}(x). The x- and y-coordinates will be switched.
We can make a non-invertible function invertible by restricting its domain so it doesn't have repeated values.

Because the input and output are switched for a function and its inverse, then so are the domain and range. The domain of an invertible function is the same as the range of its inverse function. Similarly, the range of an invertible function is the same as the domain of its inverse function.
